term.name: East San Fernando Valley Transit Corridor Project
term.displayName: East San Fernando Valley Transit Corridor Project

field.name: East San Fernando Valley Transit Corridor
East San Fernando Valley Transit Corridor Project

definition:
The East San Fernando Valley Transit Corridor is a proposed light rail transit corridor in Los Angeles's San Fernando Valley, running on a north/south route along Van Nuys Boulevard and San Fernando Road. Metro selected its preferred route as light rail without tunneling, "Alternative Six". The final Environmental Impact Report is currently in progress and the light rail line is scheduled for construction in 2021 with a completion of 2027.


Metro approved the project with $1.3 billion in funds, initiating the final EIR. The northern terminus will be the Sylmar/San Fernando Metrolink station. The light rail train will run southeast for two and a half miles on San Fernando Road to Van Nuys Boulevard. It then heads south on Van Nuys Boulevard for five miles reaching the Van Nuys Metrolink station. Its southern terminus will be the Van Nuys Orange Line station near Van Nuys City Hall two miles further south. The EIR is due in early 2019.

field.name: Expo Blvd Lrt Const Phase Ii
Standardized Tpss Procurement For Expo Phase 2 (Metro Hold Back) & Foothill Extension Phase 2A
Downtown Los Angeles to Culver City
Mid-City Exposition Light Rail Transit Project

definition:
The Exposition Light Rail Transit Project is a 9.6 mile line beginning at the existing 7th/Metro Center Station in Downtown Los Angeles at its eastern terminus. The line will then proceed south for approximately two miles before turning west near Exposition Park and the University of Southern California and continue west along the former railroad right-of-way to Culver City. The western terminus of the line is at the Venice/Washington
station.
The line will run in the abandoned railroad right-of-way on Exposition Boulevard that was purchased by MTA in 1990. The route runs parallel to the Santa Monica Freeway (I-10), one of the most heavily traveled and congested freeways in the nation.
The Exposition Light Rail Transit project will include seven new stations and upgrades to three existing stations, providing a total of ten stations for the length of the initial segment of the route to Culver City. The alignment will primarily be at-grade.

term.name: Gold Line Eastside Transit Corridor Phase 2
term.displayName: Gold Line Eastside Transit Corridor Phase 2

field.name: Gold Line Eastside Extension to South El Monte
Gold Line Eastside Extension to Whittier
Gold Line Eastside Extension to Whittier or South El Monte
Gold Line Eastside Transit Corridor Phase 2

note:
A Supplemental/Recirculated Draft EIS/EIR is anticipated to be available for public review in mid 2020.
Construction is scheduled to begin in 2029 and service by 2035, though the project's timeline is expected to be accelerated under the Twenty-eight by '28 initiative.
definition:
The Gold Line Eastside Transit Corridor Phase 2 is a planned transit corridor connecting Downtown Los Angeles by extending the Gold Line in East Los Angeles to San Gabriel Valley cities of Los Angeles County. LA Metro Rail is currently constructing the Foothill Extension to Montclair in the northern area of the San Gabriel Valley expected to be completed by 2026.

Metro narrowed the options to two alternatives and are currently preparing to publish a new Re-Initiated Draft Environmental Studies and Advanced Conceptual Engineering for public comment.

Northern San Gabriel San Bernardino Valley Rail Transit Cooridor
Union Station to Sierra Madre Villa
Interstate 10 ExpressLanes/Interstate 605 to the San Bernardino Line

definition:
2019: Caltrans is currently constructing High Occupancy Vehicle (HOV) lanes on I‐10
between I‐605 and SR‐57 to create a continuous ExpressLane/HOV lane
between Alameda Street and Haven Avenue (I‐15)
Completed segments:
• LA/San Bernardino County Line to Haven Avenue – Completed 2000
• SR‐57 to LA/San Bernardino County line – Completed 2003
• I‐605 to Puente Avenue ‐ Completed 2013
In construction segments:
• Puente Avenue to Citrus Street ‐ Expected completion December 2019
• Citrus Street to SR‐57 ‐ Expected completion Summer 2021


San Bernardino County Transportation Authority is planning to
implement ExpressLanes on I‐10 between the Los Angeles/San
Bernardino County line and Redlands
• Two ExpressLanes in each direction with one lane in a short
segment approaching Los Angeles County
• Projected opening date Summer 2023 (Segment 1 – County line
to I‐15)


Metro is evaluating:

• Conversion of single HOV lane in each direction to ExpressLanes
• Conversion of single HOV lane into ExpressLanes and the addition
of a second ExpressLane in each direction (non‐standard lane
widths)
• Conversion of single HOV lane into ExpressLanes and the addition
of a second ExpressLane in each direction (standard lane widths)
• Conversion of HOV lanes to ExpressLanes and addition of one
reversible ExpressLane ‐ this will require further analysis with
Caltrans
Review: Should i-10 ExpressLanes Extension have special relationship to Metro ExpressLanes, similar to "has transportationPhase-transportationmethod"?

definition: Segment 3 of the Metro Rail project is the continuation of the Mainline from Hollywood/Vine to Lankershim Blvd./Chandler Blvd., and is scheduled to be in operation in the future (6.3 miles). Segment 3 also includes an East Los Angeles extension from Union Station to 1st/Lorena (3.7 miles).
